title: The Two Baskets of Figs
shortSummary: Jeremiah 24 presents a vision of two baskets of figs symbolizing the fate of the people of Judah after the Babylonian captivity. The good figs represent the exiles whom God will bless and restore, while the bad figs symbolize those left in Jerusalem and Egypt who face judgment and destruction. This chapter highlights God’s sovereign judgment and promise of restoration for His people.
timeline: c. 586 BC - Babylonian Captivity of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and conveys God's vision and message regarding Judah's fate.

keyCharacters.name: Jeconiah
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jehoiakim and king of Judah, taken captive to Babylon, representing the exiled good figs.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah during the final siege of Jerusalem, representing the bad figs who face judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon who carried away Jeconiah and others into captivity, initiating Judah’s exile.

definitions.definition: Another name for the Babylonians, the empire that conquered Judah and took many into exile.
In this context, meaning bad, worthless, or rotten; describing figs that are spoiled and inedible.
A spiritual renewal where God grants His people understanding and desire to follow Him sincerely.
Expressions of public shame and disgrace, indicating how the exiles will be mocked among nations.

outline.heading: The Vision of Two Baskets of Figs
outline.description: Jeremiah sees two baskets of figs placed before the temple—one with good figs and one with bad—symbolizing the divided fate of Judah’s people after the Babylonian captivity.

outline.heading: God’s Promise to the Exiles
outline.description: God declares that the good figs represent the exiles in Babylon whom He will watch over, restore, and bless with a renewed heart to know Him.

outline.heading: Judgment on Those Remaining in Judah and Egypt
outline.description: The bad figs symbolize King Zedekiah, the princes, and others who remain in the land or flee to Egypt; they will face severe judgment, exile, and destruction.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign plan even in times of hardship, knowing He can bring restoration from exile or difficulty.
Seek a renewed heart to know the Lord fully, as God promises to give His people understanding and devotion.
Recognize the consequences of rebellion against God and the importance of obedience to His commands.
Encourage fellow believers by reminding them of God’s faithfulness to restore and bless His people.

keyVerses.text: For I will set mine eyes upon them for good, and I will bring them again to this land: and I will build them, and not pull them down; and I will plant them, and not pluck them up.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s promise of restoration and His protective care over His people.

keyVerses.text: And I will give them an heart to know me, that I am the LORD: and they shall be my people, and I will be their God: for they shall return unto me with their whole heart.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the spiritual renewal God grants to His people, enabling true knowledge and relationship with Him.

keyVerses.text: And I will deliver them to be removed into all the kingdoms of the earth for their hurt, to be a reproach and a proverb, a taunt and a curse, in all places whither I shall drive them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns of the severe judgment and disgrace awaiting those who reject God’s ways.
